contentList.content: As you invest these embroidered strips of cloth, you must meditate and slowly wrap them around your hands. These handwraps have weapon runes etched into them to give your unarmed attacks the benefits of those runes, making your unarmed attacks work like magic weapons.

Greater Striking Handwraps of Mighty Blows +2

As you invest these embroidered strips of cloth, you must meditate and slowly wrap them around your hands. These handwraps have weapon runes etched into them to give your unarmed attacks the benefits of those runes, making your unarmed attacks work like magic weapons.

Adventurers who don't wear armor travel in durable clothing. Though it's not armor and uses your unarmored defense proficiency, it still has a Dex Cap and can grant an item bonus to AC if etched with armor potency runes.

This item appears to be an ordinary semiprecious stone and is typically mounted on a brooch or ring, but the stone is, in fact, an eyeball. This illusion can be seen through with true seeing or similar magic, and anyone who interacts with the item feels its wet and sticky surface, allowing them to attempt to disbelieve the illusion (DC 19). Many hags claim a hag eye is more effective if plucked from a living, awake creature, but this is likely just a convenient excuse for sadism.
The hag eye produces no direct benefit for the wearer, but allows the hag who created it, or any member of her coven, can peer through the eye using the Seek action. This has no range limit, provided the hag is on the same plane.

2 Actions
Range 30 feet
Targets 1 creature
Defense Will
You plant fear in the target; it must attempt a Will save
Critical Success The target is unaffected.
Success The target is frightened 1.
Failure The target is frightened 2.
Critical Failure The target is frightened 3.
Tiny silver hooks decorate these fine silk gloves. They grant a +1 item bonus to Sleight of Hand and allow you to cast telekinetic hand as an innate occult spell.
Tiny silver hooks decorate these fine silk gloves. They grant a +2 item bonus to Sleight of Hand and allow you to cast telekinetic hand as an innate occult spell.

This wizardly hat has a little embroidered rabbit inside its lining - the rabbit is called Snowball, and once he was lost, never to be found.
This hat comes in many forms, such as a colorful turban or a pointy hat with a brim, and is adorned with symbols or runes. It grants you a +1 item bonus to Arcana checks and allows you to cast the shield cantrip as an arcane innate cantrip.

This wizardly hat has a little embroidered rabbit inside its lining - the rabbit is called Snowball, and once he was lost, never to be found.
This large, fancy hat grants a +2 bonus and can be activated.
Activate—Hat Spell 3 Actions; Frequency once per day; Effect You doff the hat, causing magical energy to pour from it. You summon a creature from the hat.

Magical enhancements make this weapon strike true. Attack rolls with this weapon gain a +1 item bonus, and the weapon can be etched with one property rune.
Magical enhancements make this weapon strike true. Attack rolls with this weapon gain a +2 item bonus, and the weapon can be etched with one property rune.
A striking rune stores destructive magic in the weapon, increasing the weapon damage dice it deals to two instead of one.
A striking rune stores destructive magic in the weapon, increasing the weapon damage dice it deals to three instead of one.
Magic wards deflect attacks. Increase the armor's item bonus to AC by 1. The armor can be etched with one property rune.
Magic wards deflect attacks. Increase the armor's item bonus to AC by 2. The armor can be etched with one property runes.
Resilient runes imbue armor with additional protective magic. This grants the wearer a +1 item bonus to saving throws.
With a thought, you become invisible for 1 minute, gaining the effects of a 2nd-rank invisibility spell.

Usage etched onto armor
If you reach 0 hit points, you regain [1] instead of becoming Downed.
A fine stone for carving, often found at the base of volcanoes.
Brilliant, purple, and rumoured to drive away oni.
Anyone can squeeze blood from a stone if the edges are sharp enough.
It's said when Shar walks upon the earth, she leaves a path of onyx behind her.
Sunlight dances off this pale golden gem, as if it were alive.
A precious mineral from the Sea of Fallen Stars, cherished by sovereigns and stonecarvers alike.
A faceted stone with little sunrises going off in its hue; redolent of Lathander, he who enriches the dawn with light.
Parents slip these stones under their children's pillows to ward off nightmares.
Green as poison, but no more dangerous than a pebble.

A deep burgundy colour, this stone seems to trap all light.
It is said kissing a sapphire will help you keep any secret - no matter how grave the sin.
A gem of the desert, birthed in flame.

Must be etched onto armor.
These symbols fortify your body's grasp on your soul, keeping it tethered when death approaches.
Activate [reaction] envision; Frequency once per day; Trigger You would be reduced to 0 Hit Points but not immediately killed; Effect You avoid being knocked out and remain at 1 Hit Point, and your wounded condition increases by 1.

1 Action;
Frequency once per day;
Effect The armor casts your choice of enlarge or shrink on you.
You soothe the wounds of a willing, living, adjacent creature, restoring 4d6+15 Hit Points to that creature. This is a healing vitality effect. You can't harm undead with this healing.
You soothe the wounds of a willing, living, adjacent creature, restoring 2d6+7 Hit Points to that creature. This is a healing vitality effect. You can't harm undead with this healing.

Made of materials scavenged from wild places, a druid's crown can be rebuilt for a variety of benefits. The crown grants you a +1 item bonus to Intimidation, depending on the material used to build the crown, and can be activated to cast Enlarge. If you wear living mantle along with the crown, the crown's item bonus increases by 1.
Activate—Grow [2 Actions] (concentrate); Frequency once per day; Effect The crown casts enlarge at 2nd rank.

If you wear living mantle along with the crown, the crown's item bonus increases by 1.
Activate—Grow [2 Actions] (concentrate); Frequency once per day; Effect The crown casts enlarge at 2nd rank.

Activate—Grow [2 Actions] (concentrate); Frequency once per day; Effect The crown casts enlarge at 2nd rank.

Activate (Interact); Frequency once per minute; Effect A ram-shaped blast of force slams into all creatures in a 30-foot cone. The blow deals 9d6 force damage and pushes the target 15 feet. The target must attempt a DC 32 Fortitude save.

Activate (Interact); Frequency once per minute; Effect A ram-shaped blast of force slams into one foe that you can see within 60 feet. The blow deals 4d6 force damage and pushes the target 10 feet. The target must attempt a DC 22 Fortitude save.

Activate (Interact); Frequency once per minute; Effect A ram-shaped blast of force slams into one foe that you can see within 60 feet. The blow deals 6d6 force damage and pushes the target 15 feet. The target must attempt a DC 22 Fortitude save.

Activate (Interact); Frequency once per minute; Effect A ram-shaped blast of force slams into one foe that you can see within 60 feet. The blow deals 3d6 force damage and pushes the target 5 feet. The target must attempt a DC 32 Fortitude save.

Activate (Interact); Frequency once per minute; Effect A ram-shaped blast of force slams into one foe that you can see within 60 feet. The blow deals 6d6 force damage and pushes the target 10 feet. The target must attempt a DC 32 Fortitude save.

Activate (Interact); Frequency once per minute; Effect A ram-shaped blast of force slams into one foe that you can see within 60 feet. The blow deals 9d6 force damage and pushes the target 15 feet. The target must attempt a DC 32 Fortitude save.

1 to 3 Actions
Range 60 feet
A ram-shaped blast of force slams into one foe that you can see within 60 feet. The number of actions you spend to Activate this Item determines the intensity of the force. The blow deals 2d6 force damage per action spent and pushes the target 5 feet per action spent. The target must attempt a DC 22 Fortitude save.

1 to 3 Actions
Range 60 feet
A ram-shaped blast of force slams into one foe that you can see within 60 feet. The number of actions you spend to Activate this Item determines the intensity of the force. The blow deals 3d6 force damage per action spent and pushes the target 5 feet per action spent. The target must attempt a DC 22 Fortitude save. When you activate the ring using 3 actions, you can disperse the force into multiple magical rams, targeting all creatures in a 30-foot cone instead of one target within 60 feet.

Activate (Interact); Frequency once per minute; Effect A ram-shaped blast of force slams into one foe that you can see within 60 feet. The blow deals 2d6 force damage and pushes the target 5 feet. The target must attempt a DC 22 Fortitude save.

This heavy iron ring is shaped to look like the head of a ram, with curling horns.
Activate [1 to 3 Actions] (Interact); Frequency once per minute; Effect A ram-shaped blast of force slams into one foe that you can see within 60 feet. The number of actions you spend to Activate this Item (from 1 to 3) determines the intensity of the force. The blow deals 2d6 force damage per action spent and pushes the target 5 feet per action spent. The target must attempt a DC 22 Fortitude save.
Critical Success The target is unaffected.
Success The target takes half damage and is pushed half the distance.
Failure The target takes full damage and is pushed the full distance.
Critical Failure The target takes double damage and is pushed twice the distance.

This heavy iron ring is shaped to look like the head of a ram, with curling horns.
Activate [1 to 3 Actions] (Interact); Frequency once per minute; Effect A ram-shaped blast of force slams into one foe that you can see within 60 feet. The number of actions you spend to Activate this Item (from 1 to 3) determines the intensity of the force. The blow deals 3d6 force damage per action spent and pushes the target 5 feet per action spent. The target must attempt a DC 32 Fortitude save. When you activate the ring using 3 actions, you can disperse the force into multiple magical rams, targeting all creatures in a 30-foot cone instead of one target within 60 feet.
Critical Success The target is unaffected.
Success The target takes half damage and is pushed half the distance.
Failure The target takes full damage and is pushed the full distance.
Critical Failure The target takes double damage and is pushed twice the distance.

These clean, white gloves never show signs of blood, even after they're used to stitch up wounds or treat other ailments. They give you a +1 item bonus to Medicine checks.
Activate—Healer's Touch [1 Action] (manipulate); Frequency once per day; Effect You soothe the wounds of a willing, living, adjacent creature, restoring 2d6+7 Hit Points to that creature. This is a healing vitality effect. You can't harm undead with this healing.

These clean, white gloves never show signs of blood, even after they're used to stitch up wounds or treat other ailments. They give you a +2 item bonus to Medicine checks.
Activate—Healer's Touch [1 Action] (manipulate); Frequency once per day; Effect You soothe the wounds of a willing, living, adjacent creature, restoring 4d6+15 Hit Points to that creature. This is a healing vitality effect. You can't harm undead with this healing.

This sprig of berry-festooned holly and mistletoe doesn't wilt or rot. It can be used as a primal locus, and it grants a +1 item bonus to Nature checks while you wear it.
Activate—Anoint [2 Actions] (manipulate); Frequency once per 10 minutes; Effect You squeeze juice from one of the berries and smear it onto a weapon made primarily of wood to cast runic weapon on it.
Activate—Bind [2 Actions] (manipulate); Frequency once per day; Effect You touch the sprig to cast plant growth.

The base of this cloak is a thick layer of moss, but it slowly picks up native plants from each area it spends time in. You gain a +2 item bonus to Nature checks. You also suffer no effects from severe cold and severe heat.
Activate—Druidic Secrets [Free Action] (concentrate); Frequency once per day; Effect You gain 1 Focus Point, which you can spend only to cast an order spell. If you don't spend this Focus Point by the end of this turn, it is lost.

Stories tell of a king who once loved his subjects so much he was willing to give his own life energy for them, using an object like the crown of the companion. Whether true or not, this majestic wooden crown bears elaborate carvings depicting that tale with images of a regal figure giving increasingly of themself to a throng of needy subjects. While wearing this crown, you gain a +1 item bonus to Diplomacy checks.
Activate [2 Actions] (concentrate, manipulate); Frequency once per day; Effect You bow to an ally within 30 feet, creating a magical bond between the two of you as if you cast share life targeting the ally. The link remains even if you move more than 30 feet away from them. At the end of the spell’s duration, your ally recovers 4d8 Hit Points and you recover half of what they recover.

1 Action (manipulate. morph); Frequency once per hour; Effect The bracers fuse temporarily with your forearms, with the claws extending to your fingertips. You gain a claw unarmed attack with the agile and finesse traits that deals 1d6 slashing damage. This lasts for 10 minutes or until you Dismiss it.
You add half your Strength modifier (if positive) to damage rolls with a propulsive ranged weapon. If you have a negative Strength modifier, you add your full Strength modifier instead.
When you hit an off-guard creature, this weapon deals 1 precision damage in addition to its normal damage.

You can use the momentum from a missed attack with this weapon to lead into your next attack. After missing with this weapon on your turn, you gain a +1 circumstance bonus to your next attack with this weapon before the end of your turn.

This weapon makes wide swinging attacks. When you attack with this weapon, you gain a +1 circumstance bonus to your attack roll if you already attempted to attack a different target this turn using this weapon.

This weapon is attached to a length of rope or chain that allows you to retrieve it after it has left your hand. If you have a free hand (including if you've just thrown a two-handed tethered weapon and have a hand holding nothing but the weapon's tether), you can use an Interact action to pull the weapon back into your grasp after you have thrown it as a ranged attack or after it has been disarmed (unless it's being held by another creature).

The weapon can be used to Trip with the Athletics skill within the weapon’s first range increment. The skill check takes a –2 circumstance penalty. You can add the weapon’s item bonus to attack rolls as a bonus to the check. A ranged trip weapon doesn’t deal any damage when used to Trip. These weapons are usually thrown.
This ranged weapon is less effective at close distances. Your attacks against targets that are at a distance within the range listed take a –2 penalty.

A brace weapon is effective at damaging moving opponents. When you Ready to Strike an opponent that moves within your reach, until the start of your next turn Strikes with the brace weapon deal an additional 2 precision damage for each weapon damage die it has.
Switch your weapon's damage to Slashing.

When a lure is attached to a combat fishing pole, it can be used to make thrown weapon attacks with a range increment of 20 feet, though the lure must then be reeled back in with an Interact action before the weapon can be used at range again (see the tethered trait). The ranged trip, tethered, thrown, and versatile P traits of the combat fishing pole only apply to thrown attacks made with a lure; throwing the pole itself leaves you with no practical way to retrieve it other than moving to its location and picking it up.

Traditionally a favored weapon in Molthune for settling disputes between military leaders, the dancer's spear has seen a recent resurgence in popularity in the neighboring kingdom of Nirmathas, largely due to its effectiveness at striking down attacking skeletons and other undead from a relatively safe distance. The combat fishing pole is a sturdy and flexible pole that can be used as a weapon in melee. When a lure is attached to a combat fishing pole, it can be used to make thrown weapon attacks with a range increment of 20 feet, though the lure must then be reeled back in with an Interact action before the weapon can be used at range again (see the tethered trait). The ranged trip, tethered, thrown, and versatile P traits of the combat fishing pole only apply to thrown attacks made with a lure; throwing the pole itself leaves you with no practical way to retrieve it other than moving to its location and picking it up. A combat fishing pole can be used alongside fishing tackle to fish, and it adds its item bonus from weapon potency runes (if any) as an item bonus on checks to fish when used in this manner.

This projectile weapon is made from horn, wood, and sinew laminated together to increase the power of its pull and the force of its projectile. Like all longbows, its great size also increases the bow's range and power. You must use two hands to fire it, and it cannot be used while mounted. Any time an ability is specifically restricted to a longbow, such as Erastil's favored weapon, it also applies to composite longbows unless otherwise stated.

You can use this weapon to trip your target with the Athletics skill even if you don’t have a free hand, knocking it prone. This uses the weapon’s reach (if different from your own) and adds the weapon’s item bonus to attack rolls as an item bonus to the Athletics check. If you critically fail a check to Trip using the weapon, you can drop the weapon to take the effects of a failure instead of a critical failure.

You can use this weapon to Disarm a target with the Athletics skill even if you don’t have a free hand. The target is disarmed on a critical success and takes a -2 circumstance penalty to attack rolls on a success. This uses the weapon’s reach (if different from your own) and adds the weapon’s item bonus to attack rolls (if any) as an item bonus to the Athletics check.

Deals an additional 3d6 persistent poison damage to Giants.
Deals an additional 3d6 persistent poison damage to Humanoids.
Deals an additional 3d6 persistent poison damage to Monstrosities.
Deals an additional 3d6 persistent poison damage to Oozes.
Deals an additional 3d6 persistent poison damage to Plants.
Deals an additional 3d6 persistent poison damage to Undead.
Deals [1] and [2] persistent, and explodes in a spray of acid that deals an additional [3].
Deals [1] and explodes in a bolt of lightning. Targets hit by the lightning take an additional [2].
Deals [1] and [2] persistent, and explodes in a spray of poison gas that deals an additional [2].
Deals [1] and [2] persistent, and explodes in a spray of poison gas that deals an additional [3].
+2 circumstance bonus to fortitude saving throws.
Deals acid damage instead of its normal damage type, and the creature then a [1] penalty to movement speed and [2] persistent.
Deals an additional [1] to all caught in the frosty explosion.
Deals [1] and shatters to deal an additional [2] to all caught in the frosty explosion.

You can use this weapon to Trip with the Athletics skill even if you don’t have a free hand. This uses the weapon’s reach (if different from your own) and adds the weapon’s item bonus to attack rolls as an item bonus to the Athletics check. If you critically fail a check to Trip using the weapon, you can drop the weapon to take the effects of a failure instead of a critical failure.
Its blades have been worn dull from years of use.
Its blades have been worn dull from years of use.
This weapon can channel energy damage. You gain the Conduct Energy free action while wielding a resonant weapon.

You can use this weapon to Shove with the Athletics skill even if you don’t have a free hand. This uses the weapon’s reach (if different from your own) and adds the weapon’s item bonus to attack rolls as an item bonus to the Athletics check. If you critically fail a check to Shove using the weapon, you can drop the weapon to take the effects of a failure instead of a critical failure.
The weapon has multiple configurations that you can switch between using an Interact action, allowing it to deal different types of damage.

On a critical hit, the weapon adds a weapon damage die of the listed size. Roll this after doubling the weapon’s damage. This increases to two dice if the weapon has a greater striking rune and three dice if the weapon has a major striking rune. For instance, a rapier with a greater striking rune deals 2d8 extra piercing damage on a critical hit. An ability that changes the size of the weapon’s normal damage dice doesn’t change the size of its deadly die.

On a critical hit, the weapon adds a weapon damage die of the listed size. Roll this after doubling the weapon’s damage. This increases to two dice if the weapon has a greater striking rune and three dice if the weapon has a major striking rune. For instance, a rapier with a greater striking rune deals 2d8 extra piercing damage on a critical hit. An ability that changes the size of the weapon’s normal damage dice doesn’t change the size of its deadly die.

The fatal trait includes a die size. On a critical hit, the weapon’s damage die increases to that die size instead of the normal die size, and the weapon adds one additional damage die of the listed size.

The fatal trait includes a die size. On a critical hit, the weapon’s damage die increases to that die size instead of the normal die size, and the weapon adds one additional damage die of the listed size.

The fatal trait includes a die size. On a critical hit, the weapon’s damage die increases to that die size instead of the normal die size, and the weapon adds one additional damage die of the listed size.

The fatal trait includes a die size. On a critical hit, the weapon’s damage die increases to that die size instead of the normal die size, and the weapon adds one additional damage die of the listed size.
Attacks with this weapon are nonlethal, and are used to knock creatures unconscious instead of kill them.

Razing weapons are particularly good at damaging objects, and structures. Whenever you deal damage to an object (including constructs), or structure with a razing weapon, the object takes an amount of additional damage equal to double the number of weapon damage dice.

This weapon becomes more dangerous as you build momentum. When you attack with it more than once on your turn, the second attack gains a circumstance bonus to damage equal to the number of weapon damage dice, and each later attack gains a circumstance bonus to damage equal to double the number of damage dice.

This weapon is edged with curved teeth that leave bleeding wounds. When you hit a creature with this weapon, it deals an additional 1 persistent bleed damage. This increases to 2 persistent bleed damage if the weapon has a greater striking rune.

This wooden club is embedded with razorsharp blades, typically made of obsidian. The blades are inserted vertically around two sides of the weapon, leaving a central bludgeoning surface available for bashing.
This large and well-made crossbow requires some training to use effectively, but it's assembled with a cutting-edge firing mechanism that maximizes its speed, power, and accuracy.
This weapon is a heavier, two-handed version of the curved-bladed scimitar. It is weighted toward the blade's end, making it a powerful slashing weapon.
Deals [1], and all other creatures within 5 feet take [2] splash.
Deals [1], and all other creatures within 5 feet take [2] splash.
This weapon is attached to a length of rope or chain that allows you to retrieve it after it has left your hand.
Use an Interact action to retrieve your tethered weapon.

If you have a free hand (including if you've just thrown a two-handed tethered weapon and have a hand holding nothing but the weapon's tether), you must use an Interact action to pull the weapon back into your grasp after you have thrown it as a ranged attack.

A weapon with the hampering trait includes a disruptive limb or flange. After you hit with the weapon, you can use an Interact action to give the target a –10-foot circumstance penalty to all Speeds. The penalty ends after the target takes a move action, at the start of your next turn, if you attack with the weapon, or if you move out of reach of the target, whichever comes first.

You have a –10-foot circumstance penalty to all Speeds. The penalty ends after the target takes a move action, at the start of your next turn, if you attack with the weapon, or if you move out of reach of the target, whichever comes first.

You favor bows and other elegant weapons. You have <LSTag Tooltip="Proficiency">Proficiency</LSTag> with the elf trait plus the Longbows, Composite Longbows, Rapiers, Shortbows, and Composite Shortbows.

Your kin have instilled in you an affinity for hard-hitting weapons, and you prefer these to more elegant arms. You have <LSTag Tooltip="Proficiency">Proficiency</LSTag> with the dwarf trait plus the Battle Axe, Pick, and Warhammer.

You favor unusual weapons tied to your people, such as blades with curved and peculiar shapes. You have <LSTag Tooltip="Proficiency">Proficiency</LSTag> with the gnome trait plus the Glaive and Kukri.

Others might look upon them with disdain, but you know that the weapons of your people are as effective as they are sharp. You have <LSTag Tooltip="Proficiency">Proficiency</LSTag> with the goblin trait.

You favor traditional halfling weapons, so you've learned how to use them more effectively. You have <LSTag Tooltip="Proficiency">Proficiency</LSTag> with the halfling trait plus the Sling and Shortsword.
You have <LSTag Tooltip="Proficiency">Proficiency</LSTag> with the kobold trait plus the Greatpick, Light Pick, and Pick.
In combat, you favor the brutal weapons that are traditional for your orc ancestors. You have <LSTag Tooltip="Proficiency">Proficiency</LSTag> with the orc trait plus the Falchion and Greataxe.

The armor covers you so completely that it provides benefits against some damaging effects. On Reflex saves to avoid a damaging effect, such as a fireball, you add a +3 modifier instead of your Dexterity modifier.
You can position yourself in the armor or reposition its articulated pieces to better protect against ranged attacks.
You can position yourself in the armor or reposition its articulated pieces to better protect against melee attacks.

You can position yourself in the armor or reposition its articulated pieces to better protect against some attacks. If you're trained in this armor, while wearing it you can spend a single action to gain a +1 circumstance bonus to AC against a certain type of attack until the start of your next turn. The entrench trait lists the type of attack this bonus applies against, typically entrench melee or entrench ranged.
Hobgoblins use these polearms both as standard issue for aggressive military units and on an individual basis for hunting fugitives.
Attempt to trip a creature at range, using Athletics with a –2 penalty.
Your weapon is resonating with acidic energy.
Your weapon is resonating with freezing energy.
Your weapon is resonating with electrical energy.
Your weapon is resonating with flaming energy.
Your weapon is resonating with sonic energy.
You channel elemental energy through your weapon after casting a spell that dealt the corresponding damage type.
You channel elemental energy through your weapon after casting spells that dealt the corresponding damage type.

Specialized grooves lined with unique, alchemically treated metals capable of retaining energy score the length of this sword. The first wish blades originated from genie smiths, and the knowledge of these weapons has been passed on to generations of geniekin, earning them the name wish blades.

Much like a wish blade, the length of this knife is scored with intricate grooves capable of retaining energy. Wish knives are lighter than their counterparts, making them the weapon of choice for agile combatants.

You can use this weapon to Shove with the Athletics skill even if you don’t have a free hand. This uses the weapon’s reach (if different from your own) and adds the weapon’s item bonus to attack rolls as an item bonus to the Athletics check. If you critically fail a check to Shove using the weapon, you can drop the weapon to take the effects of a failure instead of a critical failure.

This armor is so heavy and bulky it slows you down no matter what. You take a –5 penalty to all your Speeds (to a minimum of a 5-foot Speed). This is separate from and in addition to the armor's Speed penalty, and affects you even if your Strength or an ability lets you reduce or ignore the armor's Speed penalty.

The armor has moving parts or other complications that lengthen the wearer's initial reaction time. While wearing the armor, you take a –1 penalty to initiative checks. If you don't meet the armor's required Strength modifier, this penalty increases to be equal to the armor's check penalty if it's worse.
Throw the lure of the fishing pole to strike your target.

When thrown, the shield is a martial thrown ranged weapon. Its damage dice and type are the same as its shield bash attack, but if the shield includes an attached weapon or integrated weapon, you can choose to attack with it instead when you throw the shield. You add your Strength modifier to damage, as typical of a thrown weapon.
Thrust or swing your shield to hit your foe with an impromptu attack.
You have <LSTag Tooltip="Proficiency">Proficiency</LSTag> with the orc trait plus the Falchion and Greataxe.
You have <LSTag Tooltip="Proficiency">Proficiency</LSTag> with the kobold trait plus the Greatpick, Light Pick, and Pick.
You have <LSTag Tooltip="Proficiency">Proficiency</LSTag> with the halfling trait plus the Sling and Shortsword.
You have <LSTag Tooltip="Proficiency">Proficiency</LSTag> with the goblin trait.
You have <LSTag Tooltip="Proficiency">Proficiency</LSTag> with the gnome trait plus the Glaive and Kukri.
You have <LSTag Tooltip="Proficiency">Proficiency</LSTag> with the elf trait plus the Longbows, Composite Longbows, Rapiers, Shortbows, and Composite Shortbows.
You have <LSTag Tooltip="Proficiency">Proficiency</LSTag> with the dwarf trait plus the Battle Axe, Pick, and Warhammer.

This massive bow is made from bone or wood reinforced with flexible metal strips and strung with reinforced cord. Designed by hobgoblin engineers to take down shielded opponents, the phalanx piercer fires heavy, iron-shod bolts.

This hard but flexible longsword-length piece of wood looks more like a pole than a weapon, but can be deadly in the right hands. While generally not used for combat outside of Song’o culture, some halflings have become so proficient as to make it just as effective as a blade in a fight. Many halflings will even sing to maintain a certain tempo and rhythm during combat. It deals 1d6 bludgeoning damage. A fighting stick is a martial one-handed melee weapon in the club weapon group
A larger version of the asymmetrical, wavy-bladed kris, this double-edged sword is effective at creating grievous injuries.
This short-bladed, single-edged sword is typically carried as part of a pair alongside a katana.

A bec de corbin is a spiked polearm that uses a hammer head to help balance the spike. The hammer portion can be used as a secondary striking surface, while the spike or fluke is specially designed to punch through armor and shields.

This small axe sports a spike opposite the blade that aids in climbing and is useful in clearing obstacles, such as fallen rigging. This weapon is common in the High Seas region, on the Isle of Kortos and within azarketi settlements.

The aklys is a throwing club with a hook on one end and a lengthy cord attached to the other. Though aklyses aren’t available in most shops, one might be purchased for 5 gp from a vendor that specializes in strange weapons.
This specialized club is designed for throwing and useful in both combat and hunting. Tripkees use them to take down creatures that hide high in treetops.

From a central metal ring, four tapering metal blades extend like points on a compass rose. When gripping a starknife from the center, the wielder can use it as a melee weapon. It can also be thrown short distances.

These hooked staffs are popular among Senghor fishers and warriors alike. A gaff sized for a Medium creature is a common martial weapon in the club group. It deals 1d6 bludgeoning damage and has 1 Bulk. It requires one hand to use and has the trip and versatile P weapon traits. Gaffs are readily available in Senghor and nearby settlements for 1 gp.
This thick club is inset with sharp teeth, typically from a shark, that easily tear flesh. It's the preferred weapon of many Minatan warriors.

A sap has a soft wrapping around a dense core, typically a leather sheath around a lead rod. Its head is wider than its grip to disperse the force of a blow, as the weapon's purpose is to knock out its victim rather than to draw blood.

The Lord of Murder wasn't always a lord. He was once just a petty killer. When Bhaal first drew blood in a Baldurian back-alley, it dropped to the ground and lingered. When he ascended, this dried blood-drop grew, warped - and became sharp.
Essentially a longer version of the scimitar, this traditional elven weapon has a thinner blade than its cousin.

A spraysling is similar to a standard sling but with a wider cup fitted with a thin blade affixed to the cup's edges. When used to make an attack with a specially prepared packet of spray pellets, the razor slices open the packet and the weapon launches a cluster of stinging pellets.
The spearhead of this weapon is in the shape of a long leaf.
This halfling weapon looks like a long, two-pronged fork and is used as both a weapon and a cooking implement.

A heavy, weighted cube of metal at the end of a long chain, the dorn-dergar is used by dwarven berserkers and sappers who specialize in breaking through lines of shielded opponents or disabling enemy siege weapons.
This large flail has a long shaft connected to a shorter piece of stout wood or metal that's sometimes inlaid with spikes.

A fauchard is similar to a glaive, save that its cutting edge is along the concave side. Fauchards are favored by Crimson Reclaimers for hacking through waves of zombies. The fauchard is a martial melee weapon.
This single-bladed bearded axe has a jagged blade that's perfect for separating bone from tendon and cartilage.

Invented by Belkzen's zealous Steel-Eaters, the butchering axe has an oversized head and a long, thick haft counterbalanced with steel or stone. The weapon's sweeping strokes inflict immense damage, particularly against groups of foes, and can push dangerous opponents away to a safe distance. All of these qualities are particularly useful against the lumbering zombie hordes of the Whispering Tyrant. Correspondingly, butchering axes are often wielded by orc and half-orc Crimson Reclaimers of Lastwall.

The tetsubo is a war club constructed out of heavy wood shod with iron studs, designed for smashing through armor and defenses. A tetsubo made entirely out of metal might also be referred to as a kanabo.

This polearm bears a long, often one-sided, curved blade with a hook protruding from the blunt side of the blade, which can allow its wielder to trip opponents at a distance. Its shaft is usually 8 feet long.

This complex device is a crossbow and fires small wooden bullets known as taws. A system of blades within the launcher can rapidly reshape a taw as it's loaded, allowing the launcher to fire taws of different shapes, such as fléchettes.

Often used for hunting exceptionally large aquatic creatures, the harpoon is similar to a javelin but features a barbed head and rope tether so it (or the corpse it's attached to) can be easily retrieved.
This weapon has practical uses in both farming and butchering, thanks to the efficiency and brutality of its forward-curving blade. It can be wielded in one or two hands.
An Aldori dueling sword is a slim, single-bladed dueling sword with a slight curve and a sharp, reinforced point.
This broad-bladed sword, sometimes called the hand-and-a-half sword, has a longer grip so it can be held in one hand or used with two hands to provide extra slashing power.
The falcata is a heavy, one-handed sword with a single cutting edge, usually flaring to be wider towards the point of the weapon and narrower towards the hilt.

Also known as a zhanmadao, the exceptionally long blade of the nodachi is designed to neutralize enemy mounts and counter the advantages of cavalry units. Its shape and size make it somewhat impractical for close combat but highly effective against charging opponents.

A light mace has a short wooden or metal shaft ending with a dense metal head. Used much like a club, it delivers heavy bludgeoning blows, but with extra power derived from the head's metal ridges or spikes.
This deceptively dangerous weapon is essentially a mace with a longer haft and larger, often flanged head.
The liuyedao, or willow-leaf saber, is a common, one-handed military saber with a moderately curved blade designed for slashing and chopping attacks.

Specialized grooves lined with unique, alchemically treated metals capable of retaining energy score the length of this sword. The first wish blades originated from genie smiths, and the knowledge of these weapons has been passed on to generations of geniekin, earning them the name wish blades.

This sword has a broad blade, along which are threaded nine heavy metal rings, leading some to call it the nine-ring sword. The rings add weight to the weapon for broad swings and clash together to make noise.
Similar to a shortsword, a gladius is designed to inflict deadly stabbing wounds while still being useful as a slashing weapon.
Similar to a sickle and used in some regions to reap grain, a kama has a short, slightly curved blade and a wooden handle.
A lion scythe resembles a common sickle but is specially weighted to allow for greater power when attacking. This is a martial melee weapon.
This small, curved blade resembles a tiger's claw and is capable of delivering deep wounds.

The kestros is a type of sling that fires special ammunition with wing-shaped fins and a pointed end. The thongs of the sling are of uneven length, one shorter and one several inches longer, around an open loop to cradle the ammunition as the sling is spun.
Several short branches project from this delicate spear's shaft, each angled forward and tipped with a leaflike blade.
This polearm is a long trident with a central prong that's longer than the other two.
This gnome tool and weapon features a hammer at one end and a curved pick on the other. It's such a strange and awkward weapon that others think the gnomes are slightly erratic for using it.

As dwarves poured out of the Darklands following their Quest for Sky, the orcs driven before them adapted to their tactics—including dwarves’ heavily armored infantry charges. Surviving orcs developed a response: a weapon that combines a spear and maul to crush heavy armor and skewer charging foes. Although rarely seen today, the weapon is remarkably effective in the right situation.
Ogres are known for using immense, curved picks called ogre hooks.
This ingenious kobold pick conceals several hidden traps that the wielder can activate to trick and befuddle foes with a variety of damaging blades and bludgeoning surfaces.
This pick has a longer handle and broader head than a regular pick. It is too heavy to wield in one hand.

Glued together with tree sap and wrapped with cloth, the draw of this patched-up bow is less than ideal.
A common sword, passed between hands both fresh and battle-scarred.
The pike's tip is battered and bent, fit for neither soldier nor scoundrel.
Brittle, warped wood makes this staff better suited to kindling fires than to winning wars.
This splintering cane has struck enough victims to have cracked from overuse.
Worn by Shar's most loyal zealots, the mere sight of it strikes fear in the heart of even the bravest of souls.
Though time has tarnished this armour's metal and cracked its leather, the black sheen of Shar's symbol shines eternal from its chestpiece.
The tip of this club has snapped off, its wood rotten to the core.

Free Action (concentrate); Frequency once per day; Effect You gain 1 Focus Point, which you can spend only to cast an order spell. If you don't spend this Focus Point by the end of this turn, it is lost.

This single-edged blade has a guardless hilt. Often decorated with elaborate etchings, a flyssa is longer than most daggers but shorter than average for most swords, making it useful in close and pitched combat.
A large spherical head with a spike on top sits mounted to a long shaft.
This curved sickle sword has a pointed tip, allowing it to be swung in wide arcs or thrust vertically around enemy defenses. The tip of a khopesh is hooked and can be used to trip an opponent.
The blade of this foot-long knife curves inward and lacks a cross guard at the hilt.
This medium-length sword has a wide blade and long grip. Though it is typically used to hack through heavy foliage, the machete can also be used as a deadly weapon.
This parrying dagger features a robust guard to protect the wielder's hand.
A pick designed solely for combat has a sturdy wooden shaft and a heavy, pointed head to deliver devastating blows.
Derived from a farming tool used to mow down long grains and cereals, this weapon has a long wooden shaft with protruding handles, capped with a curved blade set at a right angle.

Bones, some solid and others splintered, are affixed to metal chains at the end of a long stick to form a powerful flail. Many kholo warriors insist the vicious crack the weapon makes as it strikes loosens fragments of the soul like husks struck from grains.
Longer, and with less curve than a scimitar, this blade is ubiquitous in guard and mercenary groups throughout Casmaron.
Meteor shields are specifically designed with throwing in mind. A meteor shield is made from thin steel and has quick-release straps, allowing for easy, long-distance throws.

This very small shield is a favorite of duelists and quick, lightly armored warriors. It's typically made of steel and strapped to your forearm. You can Raise a Shield with your buckler as long as you have that hand free or are holding a light object that's not a weapon in that hand.
Several small blades line the outside edge of this steel shield. This specialized throwing shield is common among warriors in the Mwangi Expanse, where its blades can cut down foliage as it flies.

This very small shield is a favorite of duelists and quick, lightly armored warriors. It's typically made of steel and strapped to your forearm. You can Raise a Shield with your buckler as long as you have that hand free or are holding a light object that's not a weapon in that hand. Blood splatters this shield - both inside and out.

These massive shields can be used to provide cover to nearly the entire body. Due to their size, they are typically made of wood reinforced with metal.
Getting the higher AC bonus for a tower shield requires using the Take Cover action while the shield is raised.

These massive shields can be used to provide cover to nearly the entire body. Due to their size, they are typically made of wood reinforced with metal.
Getting the higher AC bonus for a tower shield requires using the Take Cover action while the shield is raised.

These massive shields can be used to provide cover to nearly the entire body. Due to their size, they are typically made of wood reinforced with metal.
Getting the higher AC bonus for a tower shield requires using the Take Cover action while the shield is raised.
The side of this shield has a slightly lighter colour - as if part of it was cut away and replaced.
Activate (manipulate); Frequency once per hour; Effect Sticky, flammable webbing sprays in a 30-foot cone as you strum the lute’s strings. It slows creatures within and possibly Enwebs them.

Life shot is a special cartridge that carries a small dose of elixir of life. A creature hit by activated life shot takes no damage from the successful attack, instead receiving [1] healing and gaining a [2] item bonus to Fortitude saving throws for 1 minute.
You gain a [1] item bonus to Fortitude saving throws for 10 minutes.

These cartridges are filled with sticky clear glue. When a glue bullet hits, a syrupy webbing coats the target and sticks to the ground or a nearby surface, hindering their movement. The target takes a [1] circumstance penalty to its Speeds, or until it Escape against a DC of 18. On a critical hit, the target is also immobilized until it Escapes.
Send a small rocket at a foe, blasting the target and inflicting <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="COLOR_SPRAY">Colour Spray</LSTag>.
Send a rocket of firework-flame at a foe, blasting the target, nearby creatures, and inflicting <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="COLOR_SPRAY">Colour Spray</LSTag> on the target.
Throw this alien bulb at a target and possibly pull in nearby objects and creatures.
The barbs inside this bulb explode on impact, making all nearby creatures <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="BLEEDING">Bleed</LSTag>.
Throw this slime-covered bulb at a target to coat it, the ground, and anything nearby in caustic brine.
Each creature in 20ft radius must make a Dexterity Saving Throw. On a failed save, they take [1]. On a successful save, only half as much.
Throw a net to <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="NET">Ensnare</LSTag> your target.
<LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_Help">Helping</LSTag> the target frees them from the net.
Shards of stone shatter in all directions.
A small brazier falls, dealing [1] to all targets in a [2] radius.
A brazier falls, dealing [1] to all targets in a [2] radius.
Ignite when struck with Fire damage.
The smokepowder inside explodes when ignited, damaging everything in the vicinity.
The smokepowder inside explodes when ignited, damaging everything in the vicinity.
Automatically <LSTag Tooltip="CriticalHit">Critically Hits</LSTag> objects and environments.
The oil inside explodes when ignited, damaging everything in the vicinity.
Holy water deals 1d6 spirit damage and 1 spirit splash damage. Holy water can damage only creatures with the unholy trait.
Fling a Flashblinder bomb that <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="BLINDED">Blinds</LSTag> foes.
This flask filled with corrosive acid deals 1 acid damage, [1], and [2] splash damage.
Alchemist's fire is a combination of volatile liquids that ignite when exposed to air. Alchemist's fire deals [1] damage, [2] persistent damage, and [3] splash damage.
Unholy water deals 1d6 spirit damage and 1 spirit splash damage. Unholy water can damage only creatures with the holy trait.
Holy water deals 1d6 spirit damage and 1 spirit splash damage. Holy water can damage only creatures with the unholy trait.
Unholy water deals 1d6 spirit damage and 1 spirit splash damage. Unholy water can damage only creatures with the holy trait.
Alchemist's fire is a combination of volatile liquids that ignite when exposed to air. Alchemist's fire deals [1] damage, [2] persistent damage, and [3] splash damage.
Alchemist's fire is a combination of volatile liquids that ignite when exposed to air. Alchemist's fire deals [1] damage, [2] persistent damage, and [3] splash damage.
You are taking persistent fire damage until you make a DC 15 flat check at the end of your turn.
You are taking persistent fire damage until you make a DC 15 flat check at the end of your turn.
You are taking persistent fire damage until you make a DC 15 flat check at the end of your turn.
Bottled lightning is packed with volatile reagents that create a blast of electricity when they're exposed to air. Bottled lightning deals [1] damage and [2] splash damage.
Bottled lightning is packed with volatile reagents that create a blast of electricity when they're exposed to air. Bottled lightning deals [1] damage and [2] splash damage.
Bottled lightning is packed with volatile reagents that create a blast of electricity when they're exposed to air. Bottled lightning deals [1] damage and [2] splash damage.
When this pebble hits a creature or a hard surface, it explodes with a deafening bang. A blasting stone deals [1] damage and [2] splash damage.
When this pebble hits a creature or a hard surface, it explodes with a deafening bang. A blasting stone deals [1] damage and [2] splash damage.
